Inclusionary housing policies have shown to be effective in many urban areas where there is a high demand for affordable housing and a clear need to address the issue of homelessness. However, the effectiveness of this policy may depend on many factors, including the local housing market, the availability of funding and resources, and the political will to implement such a policy. Inclusionary housing policies may be more challenging to implement in smaller cities or rural areas where there may be a lower demand for affordable housing and fewer resources available to support the development of such units.

Nevertheless, in some smaller cities, inclusionary housing policies have been successfully implemented, provided that there is a clear need for affordable housing and a coordinated effort between the city government, developers, and community organizations. In rural areas, alternative housing solutions may be necessary, such as creating co-housing communities or developing tiny homes or modular housing units that are affordable and energy-efficient. Ultimately, the effectiveness of any policy will depend on local conditions, available resources, and the ability of stakeholders to collaborate and work together to address the issue of affordable housing and homelessness in their communities.
